title: Wednesday, 6th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
RA HELLO
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Good morning. Welcome. Hi. Okay, so where we at?

Blank canvas good morning everyone
OnYourRight Morning all
RA Nasdaq reached ATH last night
Soundbuy Morning
Fox RPC please big drop

This is Markets Live, FTAlphaville's daily 11am thingmy that starts at 11.08am sharp.

Soundbuy I could go for the obvious.......
Kirkie 11.08 is the new 11.03.... ;)
RA does it continue to 12:08 then too?
BE11:10am

And rather than waffle about macro or put up a picture of a chap in a suit, let's start with something more relevant to our interests.

OnYourRight @Fox..... my error I got confused and thought you were talking about NASDAQ
11:11 am
BE11:12am

According to Northern Trust analyst Paul Moran, RPC management has been encouraged to pursue value-destructive acquisitions by “innovative” bonus schemes and “some of the most aggressive accounting we have seen”.

He argued that RPC’s definitions of adjusted profit and free cash flow had been inconsistent over the past five years, and had flattered the figures in ways that sometimes “defy accounting logic”. And by stepping up the pace of acquisitions over the 12 months, RPC had masked its structurally weak pricing power and labour cost inflation, Northern Trust told clients.

BE11:12am

“We accept that a rights-issue funded, value destroying roll-up story can continue to report adjusted EPS growth for as long as shareholders are willing to fund it,” the broker said. “But should the hitherto supportive appetite for rights issues fade, we think shareholders will find a structurally challenged, low margin, highly levered, sub cost-of-capital business trading on circa 23 times [current year] earnings on our estimates, an undeserved 50 per cent premium to the market.”

zee who are the lenders of Agean.. who is exposed?
BE11:13am

So .... yeah .... if you're facing allegations that you're running the books too hot, don't print full-year numbers that show earnings and cash conversion going in opposite directions.

Badger I'm impressed that markets live has aligned itself with train timetabling techniques from Northern. Others are less advanced or in tune with their followers. (Still good even on an emergency timetable though!)
Fox Current RPC P/E nearer 10 though?
Mouselet Good morning assorted people
11:13 am
BE11:14am

Here's the update from Paul Moran (of Northern Trust Capital Markets, as we've been told to call them).

BE11:14am

The EBITDA at £590M is a small miss vs consensus, given the FX and polymer moves, this is disappointing. The FCF looks low; we get just £160M, which is a miss, cash taxes are higher (finally) and interest costs are higher, as is capex. Working capital more than reversed to -22M headwind and the one offs are about inline (new presentation of FCF so it is difficult to be exact at first look). The FY18 organic growth is 2.8% which is good and typical for RPC, but not flowing through into profits, which has been our point. The Depreciation charge looks LOW vs guidance, are they holding back here to make EBIT look good YoY in the bridge? Will be able to check when the slides come out. Given technical guidance, if you are assuming an extra £10M on EBITDA in FY19, with one offs almost gone, stock is on a 6.5% FCF yield for FY19 with some questions about underlying growth. We believe that this should be higher, as profits are declining. We remain a seller.

epicurean Morning
Soundbuy Wasn't there some chat about Ent One and numbers and the'y're near an all time high...
alewis2005 morning all
Mouselet I would have thought that the Amazon/Netflix competition to cover all things in giant ladles of money would mean sticky content providers in general do well.
BE11:15am

Against that we have Panmure Gordon, who are defenders of management and buyers up to £12. Though they know that such arguments ain't going to play on a day like this.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

As expected provisions have more than halved (£53.3m Mar-18 vs £108.4m Mar-17). We believe this is a key indication that one-off items are directly related to the acquisitions and the associated restructuring of the business, rather than an attempt to mask the underlying profitability of the business

epicurean @BE my apologies for making repeated silly mistakes yesterday. Will pay attention in the future when commenting.
BE11:16am

But!

BE11:16am

Whilst net debt ended broadly in-line with estimates £1,139m
(Mar-18) vs forecast range of £1,038m to £1,169m, cash conversion has moved backwards. We estimate that FCF was £259m (post tax, exceptional items and maintenance capex) vs our estimate of £288m. Our provisional estimates show conversion at 78%, down from 82%. The reason for this unexpected contraction was a significant investment in working capital. Within the mix, there was a £39.3m investment in inventories, £29.5m investment in receivables. Management has indicated some of this is seasonal and some reflects investment in growing the business.

Mr Diamond @zee surprised US investors let highly questionable Greek shipping / marine companies onto the capital markets.

zee @mrdiamond two hedge funds got involved.. i see exposed banks European Banks are BNP, ABN, Natixis, Credit Suisse...

The story's rather too complicated to summarise. In short, there was an activist in there that canned much of the board earlier in the year.

BE11:23am

Co also cut ties with the founder, Dimitris Melisanidis, and moving headquarters.

zee reminds you of OW events back in 2014...
Mr Diamond @zee usual shipping names - also HSH
11:24 am
BE11:24am

Who'd tried to push through an acquisition of his other company, HEC Limited.

BE11:24am

Stifel called that move "almost comical in its inappropriateness"

BE11:25am

You've also got the company missing deadlines for filings repeatedly, and you've got a dirty great convertible out there before year end.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

So ... yeah, the $200 .... Why do bad things always happen to bad companies?

BE11:26am

Stifel chucked in the towel overnight.

BE11:26am

[The write off] causes us to question the financial integrity of the company making it impossible to forecast. Additionally, the seemingly fraudulent activity into which the Justice Department is investigating casts doubts on ANW's solvency with convertible notes due November 2018 and December 2019, potentially breaking covenants with now lower net assets, and possible contraction of credit from suppliers. As such, we believe the most prudent course of action is to suspend coverage until such time as there is better information making it possible to forecast results.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

And the now-retired boilerplate .....

BE11:27am

In our view, the company could be liquidated at $10/share, but liquidation value doesn't matter if the company is destroying value which is what had been the case. With regime change we are optimistic that there may be some recapture of wasted value, but we do expect the process to be gradual and occasionally painful, so we prefer to wait until the path forward is more apparent before recommending the shares.

BE11:27am

Fun story.

11:27 am
undefined

Okay, what else? There's Smurfit, inevitably.

Smurfit Kappa Group PLC (SKG:LSE): Last: 2,974, up 54 (+1.85%), High: 3,058, Low: 2,874, Volume: 906.75k

Going up on a bid being pulled, which is an odd thing. But the 7% pullback over the past few days is probably more significant than this morning's move.

The most effusive of which is Davy.

BE11:31am

The fundamentals of the European packaging sector are in
excellent shape. Smurfit Kappa Group (SKG) is the leading player
in this market and therefore the most exposed to the positive
dynamics. This, combined with the deep intrinsic value of its
assets, points to significant hidden value and upside in the share
price. We are increasing our price target to 4200c, 26% above
current levels. It is little wonder therefore that SKG’s Board
rejected the proposal from International Paper.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Bear in mind here that the pre-bid unadjusted price is without Reparenco, the Dutch thing Smurfit bought during the bid period.

wayneJ Perhaps we could have a future combined Peppa Pig and Jurassic World - where the dinosaurs are let loose on Peppa and chums....
BE11:33am

Merrill says underlying trading's also going better.

BE11:33am

SKG fundamentals have improved since IP's initial approach: 1) Strong Q1, with positive outlook on box prices for 2018. 2) Reparenco deal, cheap+strategic. 3) Peers have rallied 15-25%. We model FY18E EBITDA 1494mn (+6% vs. cons). Value at7.3x 2018 EV/EBITDA vs. peers at 9.0x. Growth = re-rating potential.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

So, yeah, it appears the arbs are exiting without too much fuss.

pancakes or waffles @wayneJ not a fan of Peppa?!

BE11:35am

The obvious follow-up question is, "does International Paper now go after something else?"

Soundbuy From over the other side 3) Peers have rallied 15-25%.

Investors seem to hope not, preferring buybacks to M&A. But since there was no cash return announcement overnight, it remains quite possible that IP is still on the hunt.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Here's Stephens Inc.

BE11:37am

Investors were surprised by the Smurfit Kappa bid which represented a major departure from Sutton's previously stated strategic growth criteria. The changes were unannounced and only became widely understood after Smurfit disclosed the bid. Essentially Sutton walked away from advantaged fiber, did a 180% turn on recycled fiber, and with "profit pools" created investment criteria that could mean just about anything. Given this shifting M&A criteria and IP's "willingness to change them so abruptly," the coast is not clear. And even before today's announcement, investors had asked us if IP doesn't get Smurfit, what will they buy next.

Soundbuy Smurfit had little overlap, bad for synergies but IP were looking for European/Latin American exposure foremost.......

You'll remember Ben H in the Sunday Times talking a lot about Mondi very quietly doing a strategic review.

Here's Barclays.

BE11:46am

Overall, we were impressed by the presentations from the Merlin Magic Making team on the three new brands – Peppa Pig World of Play (“PPWoP”), Little Big City (“LBC”) and Bear Grylls Adventure (“BGA”). We think the IP and concepts are well targeted to a modern and millennial audience that desires increasingly immersive, interactive, adventure or family-based experiences. With Peppa Pig and Bear Grylls, Merlin are also leveraging strong IP. We think the opportunity is exciting if these brands work but we find it more difficult to have conviction on return targets (c14% IRR in the medium term or as Merlin define it once “settled down”) given these concepts are unproven and will require refining in their early stages. Indeed, the company are launching the new brands in the knowledge that they may not all work. We think the Bear Grylls Adventure attraction might be the riskier of the new brands given the capital investment and intensity, premium price and high marketing outlay required from the outset as a destination attraction.

BE11:46am

Little Big City is a Kidzania clone, right?

11:46 am
BE11:46am

https://kidzania.co.uk/

Excel Developer chicken bhunanza!
BE11:49am

Peppa Pig has extremely high awareness, is broadcast in 180 territories in over 40 languages, and is a top 10 pre school brand (China top 1-2) in more than 70% of global markets. Merlin has signed an agreement with Entertainment One for a Peppa Pig World of Play, targeting pre school families, bringing to life Peppa’s world with physical play (including the well loved muddy puddle). Merlin has had significant success with the BBC’s CBeebies, and its work shows intention to visit a Peppa is comparable with LEGOLAND. Merlin has a near global exclusive licence for location based entertainment (excludes the U.K. and non exclusive for China / Italy until 2019) and sees ~50 potential markets, and could have multiple attractions within those. It confirmed the locations for its first 5 Peppa Pigs: Shanghai (late 2018), Beijing, Dallas, Michigan and the New York area (all 2019). It budgets for capex of £2.5-3.0m per site (around half the average Midway), delivering 140-200k annual visitors at an average £11 revenue per capita and £0.4-0.6m EBITDA. This implies a ~25% margin, a high teens EBITDA return, and at least £25m EBITDA, though we think it could be at least double that.

BE11:49am

HOLY CRAP IT HAS A MUDDY PUDDLE!

11:56 am

nichoman it wasn't that long ago that Glencore did make an approach so surely not improbable that something is in the works there. bunge share price / trading not been great and no competition now so Glencore could probably get away with low premium
hornblower @soundbuy - don't you think some/most of the DS Smith/Mondi gains driven by the IP bid for SKG
BE11:57am

For the miners in general, you have Jefferies pushing coal.

BE11:57am

We have increased our seaborne coal price forecasts to reflect supply constraints and a positive demand outlook. Chinese supply growth is a near term risk, but a sustainable collapse in seaborne prices is unlikely. Longer term, demand growth in India and other emerging markets should more than offset a decline in demand in the developed world and China. We reiterate our Buy ratings and raise our target prices for Peabody, Glencore and most other coal miners

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Christopher LaFemina's team, of course.

BE11:58am

We have increased our seaborne coal price forecasts to reflect significant supply constraints and a positive demand outlook. While coal demand may be in long-term structural decline in the developed world and China due to environmental issues, demand growth in India and other emerging economies should more than offset weaker demand elsewhere. There will be some supply growth in the seaborne coal markets, but restarts of high cost capacity in response to high prices will ultimately be needed to balance the market. A lack of investment in new mines, depletion of existing mines, and under-investment in infrastructure have been key factors in coal's resurgence, and most mining companies are unwilling to invest in new coal capacity due to demand risks and negative investor sentiment regarding coal. The ongoing bull market in coal has been greatly under-appreciated and is not over yet, in our view.

Soundbuy Fair possibility, yes..........to what degree?? No idea.........
Soundbuy Interested to see what Janus Henderson et al get up to...............
BE12:00pm

They're buyers of everything except BHP, South32 and Vale.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

We continue to be bullish on mining as we expect the supply crunch in most commodities to kick in over the next year. Glencore is well positioned to benefit from higher prices for copper and other base metals as well as ongoing strength in thermal coal markets. While falling thermal and coking coal prices will eventually be a headwind for Peabody, capital returns will continue to be supportive of the Peabody share price as the company is in the midst of a $1bn share buyback and is likely to increase its dividend as well. Like most other miners, Peabody and Glencore are undervalued free cash flow machines, based on our analysis.

undefined
Excel Developer @soundbuy: they have a twtter account, https://twitter.com/JHIAdvisorsUS
Soundbuy ........and Blackrock have been adding ..........
BE12:02pm

Since we started late, we may as well end late. Give you value for money for the ..... zero ..... you've paid.

Soundbuy Ta.....
12:02 pm
BE12:02pm

There's insurance.

Otter Perhaps we have paid, in an indirect and karmic way.
wayneJ If the FT fails to monetise its valuable audience by failing to put up ads can we be blamed?
BE12:03pm

Zurich specifically. CFO George Quinn on CNBC this morning talking about how mega mergers rarely work.

wayneJ Indeed I am sure we are all happy to sell ads and sponsorship on this side.... for a reasonable commission
BE12:03pm

I think the challenge for insurance companies is that our business is typically quite local, and I think if you do these large, global merger transactions you disrupt at least one, maybe two different businesses and it is hard to get the full value from them.

urgeview BE...any chance of posting the volumes for the FTSE Index entries when you get them please ?
red @wayneJits a social media thing. everyone has to be seen to be doing it, interacting with customers etc.
BornCynic BE - you are worth every penny of that nothing :)
Soundbuy @Otter - yep, we've kept BE away of the hotspots and drinking dens of Mayfair till midday...........
red still insurance easier to pull off than cross border banking
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

You'll remember the spike in interest around Zurich in March, which generated lots of speculative noise but not a lot that was worth reporting.

wayneJ I would have thought BE is more of a Shoreditch man?
BE12:05pm

Apropos of that, though, and entirely coincidentally, you have fantasy insurance M&A from Citi this morning.

BE12:05pm

M&A has become a hot topic for European insurers increasingly awash with solvency capital relative to target ranges. At a time of digital disruption and given the medium term threat of commoditization, now may be the time to take decisive action and position for the future. AXA’s acquisition of XL Group could be a pre-cursor of more to come. The key question is how confident insurers are about sustaining competitive advantages in this new world relative to what looks like a diminishing pool of M&A optionality. Old school cultural barriers may need to be broken down, and this looks increasingly possible in our view.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Larger M&A seems most likely in: a) genuinely transformative mega deals, b) home market consolidation and c) reinsurance/ specialty P&C. We consider one potential tie-up in each, supported by recent press reports where applicable. These include Allianz/ Zurich, ASR/ VIVAT and SCOR/ PartnerRe. Arguments for not getting deals done may be falling away, driven by the need to transform customer and service propositions.

red i would be surprised if we dont here of some big ins deals this year
BE12:06pm

Allianz-Zurich! Lightbulb There's a thought! Lightbulb A thought we might've mentioned here a few times! Lightbulb

BE12:06pm

The strategic rationale is compelling. The business mix is extremely complementary and an enlarged P&C premium base would be 54% bigger from an Allianz perspective, with no significant market share issues. Global Corporate and Commercial Lines would emerge as the largest in the world by far. Allianz’s market cap is €79bn compared with Zurich’s €39bn and any deal would be unprecedented in the industry, transforming global competitiveness. We estimate that at a 20% premium to Zurich’s share price, a deal would be 10% EPS accretive before capital synergies which could be in the region of €10bn.

Soundbuy @wayneJ - in his pursuit of RAW
fortyeight ILS are disrupting pricing.
12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

You'll remember Oliver Baete last month saying Allianz would be up for a merger of equals.

BE12:08pm

And refusing to be drawn on the idea that Zurich-Allianz makes sense.

BE12:08pm

That's the scene.

12:08 pm
undefined

BE12:12pm

Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.
